'''June Etta Downey''' (July 13, 1875- October 11, 1932) was an American psychologist who studied personality and [[handwriting]]. Downey was born and raised in Laramie, Wyoming where she received her degree in Greek and Latin from the [[University of Wyoming]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = June Etta Downey {{!}} biography - American psychologist|url = http://www.britannica.com/biography/June-Etta-Downey|website = Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate = 2015-11-08}}</ref> Throughout her life Downey wrote seven books and over seventy articles. Included in this work, Downey developed the Individual Will-Temperament Test, which was one of the first tests to evaluate character traits separately from intellectual capacity and the first to use [[psychographic]] methods for interpretation.<ref name=apadivisions>[http://www.apadivisions.org/division-35/about/heritage/june-downey-biography.aspx "June Etta Downey (1875-1932)"]. Society for the Psychology of Women.</ref>

In addition to her many published works, Downey held several prestigious positions. She chaired the Department of Psychology and Philosophy at the University of Wyoming and in doing so became the first woman to hold a head position at a state university. She was appointed to the American Psychological Association Council and became a member of the Society of Experimental Psychologists, and a [[Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]].

==Biography==

===Early life===
June Downey was born in [[Laramie, Wyoming]] to [[Stephen Wheeler Downey]] and Evangeline (Owen) Downey as the second child in a family of nine. Her father was a [[colonel]] in the [[Union Army]] and one of the founders of the [[University of Wyoming]] and her younger brother, [[Sheridan Downey]], served as US Senator from California between 1938 and 1950.<ref name="notable"/><ref>{{cite book |url= http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gPGZJ_YuMwgC&lpg=PA351&dq=june%20downey&pg=PA351#v=onepage&q&f=false |page= 351 |title= American Women of Science Since 1900 |volume= 1 |authors= Tiffany K. Wayne |publisher= ABC-CLIO |year= 2011 |accessdate= April 21, 2014}}</ref> Following education in Laramie public schools and the University of Wyoming preparatory school she entered the university to major in Greek and Latin.<ref name="notable">{{cite book |url= http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rVLOhGt1BX0C&lpg=PA515&dq=june%20downey&pg=PA514#v=onepage&q&f=false |pages= 514–515 |title= Notable American Women, 1607-1950 |author1=Edward T. James |author2=Janet Wilson James |author3=Paul S. Boyer |publisher= Harvard University Press |year= 1971 |accessdate= April 20, 2014}}</ref>

===Career===
After graduating with a [[bachelor's degree]] in 1895, Downey taught in an elementary school for a year before attending the [[University of Chicago]] to work in philosophy and psychology where she completed her [[master's degree]] in 1898.<ref name="notable"/> In 1901, Downey gained interest in experimental psychology, while attending a summer course taught by Edward Bradford Titchener at Cornell University. Returning to the University of Wyoming, Downey taught English and psychology whilst also conducting some laboratory work for a few years, under the supervision of [[James Rowland Angell]].<ref name="apadivisions" /><ref name="portraits"/>  Downey continued her education of experimental psychology under Edward B. Titchener at Cornell University. She returned to the University of Wyoming in 1905, as a Professor of Philosophy.<ref name="apadivisions"/> In 1906 she took leave from her work in order to complete her [[doctorate]]; submitting her thesis in 1908, titled 'Control Processes in Modified Handwriting', on the topic of handwriting as a measure of personality.<ref name="notable"/>

Following her graduate work, Downey was made head of her department; the first woman to be given such a position in a state university.<ref name="portraits"/> She published a number of academic papers as well as writing and occasionally publishing short stories, poems, plays, and popular articles, including a volume of poetry titled ''The Heavenly Dykes''.<ref name="smith">{{cite web |url= http://siris-archives.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siarchives&uri=full=3100001~!297411~!0#focus |title= June Etta Downey (1875-1932) |work= Smithsonian Institution Archives |accessdate= April 20, 2014}}</ref> Downey's studies focused on themes of imagery and aesthetics and were concentrated in experimental studies rather than theory.<ref name="notable"/> She was one of the first psychologists to study personality scientifically and became an expert in handwriting and handedness.<ref name="portraits">{{cite book |url= http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=w7LwgIKuSMkC&lpg=PT143&dq=june%20downey&pg=PT143#v=onepage&q=june%20downey&f=false |title= Portraits of Pioneers in Psychology, Volume 5 |publisher= Psychology Press |volume= 5 |authors= Gregory A. Kimble, Michael Wertheimer |year= 2003 |accessdate= April 21, 2014 |isbn= 113570533X}}</ref>

===Later life===
As Downey grew older she concentrated on her teaching. She published her last book, 'Creative Imagination', in 1929 tying together her interests in psychology and the arts.<ref name="portraits"/> Downey gained membership to the council of the [[American Psychological Association]] between 1923 and 1925 and was one of the first two women admitted to membership in the [[Society of Experimental Psychologists]] in 1929, along with [[Margaret Washburn]].<ref name="notable"/><ref name="portraits"/><ref name="smith"/><ref name="HB"/> Downey never married and had no children.<ref name="HB">{{cite book |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2591302514.html |title= Women in World History: A Biographical Encyclopedia |year= 2002 |accessdate= April 28, 2014 |publisher= via HighBeam {{Subscription required}} |author= Barbara Morgan}}</ref>

Downey died at her sister's home in [[Trenton, New Jersey]] in 1932 after being taken ill with [[stomach cancer]].<ref name="notable"/> Shortly after her death, Downey's family presented her private library to the University of Wyoming. The University held a memorial service for her and in 1999 she was named a finalist of 'Wyoming Citizen of the Century'.<ref name="portraits"/> [[James Rowland Angell]], whom Downey worked under for her doctorate, described her as "endowed with an unusually alert and discerning mind and with a maturity of judgment extremely infrequent in students of her age."<ref name="portraits"/>

== Major contributions ==

Downey primarily did research on [[handwriting]], but included some research on motor processes such as involuntary muscle movement and its connection to the mind and personality.<ref name="apadivisions" /> Downey had studied the practice of [[muscle reading]] from a psychological perspective.<ref>Roeckelein, Jon E. (2004). ''Imagery in Psychology: A Reference Guide''. Praeger. p. 238. ISBN 0-313-32197-3</ref>

In 1919, Downey developed the '''Downey Individual Will-Temperament Test'''. This test was one of her biggest contributions to personality psychology and was one of the first personality inventories.<ref name="apadivisions" />  The test measured personality based on handwriting. It contained 10 smaller tests that when combined could be calculated into a total score that represented one’s “will-capacity”. The Downey Individual Will-Temperament Test was arranged to represent three personality types. The three personality types are ''hairtrigger'', which is impulsive and quick, the ''witful'' type, succinct and decisive, and the ''accurate'' type, which is slow and thoughtful.<ref name="apadivisions" />

=== Other interests ===
Similar to William James and other eminent psychologists, Downey was greatly interested in the creative arts.  She wrote poems, plays, and stories throughout her life.  She even wrote the school song, "Alma Mater", for the University of Wyoming . In 1911, she published The Imaginal Reaction to Poetry, one of her most important experiments involving the arts. This study examined the images people had in response to reading poetry, she believed that variation in such images revealed differences in character.<ref name="apadivisions" />

== Major publications ==
* ''A Musical Experiment'' was published in the [[American Journal of Psychology]]<sup><ref name=":32">{{cite web|last1 = Joan, Hogan|first1 = Matthew , Broudy|title = June Etta Downey(1875-1932)|url = http://www.apadivisions.org/division-35/about/heritage/june-downey-biography.aspx|website = Society for the Psychology of Women|accessdate = 27 October 2015}}</ref></sup> 
* Her next work was her dissertation titled ''Control Process in Modified Handwriting: An Experimental Study''. In this article she studied the relationship between handwriting and temperament or personality.<sup><ref name=":32" /></sup> 
* ''Heavenly Dykes'' published in 1904  <ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title = The Heavenly Dykes|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = Badger|year = 1904|isbn = |location = Boston, MA|pages = }}</ref>
* ''Imaginal Reaction to Poetry'' published in 1911<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title = Imaginal Reaction to Poetry|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = The Laramie Republican Company|year = 1911|isbn = |location = Laramie, WY|pages = }}</ref>
* ''Graphology and the Psychology of Handwriting'' published in 1919 <ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title = Graphology and the Psychology of Handwriting|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = Warwick & York|year = 1919|isbn = |location = Baltimore, MD|pages = }}</ref>
* ''Plots and Personalities'' published in 1922<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title = Plots and Personalities|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = The Century Co|year = 1922|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref> Publisher [[The Century Company]] described this book as "the queerest book they have ever published."<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5611946/the_new_york_times/ |title= The World of Art |work= New York Times |date= 11 June 1922 |accessdate= 17 June 2016 |via= [[Newspapers.com]] |page= 68}} {{open access}}</ref>
* ''The Will-temperament and it's Testing'' published in 1923<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|title = The Will-temperament and its Testing|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = Yonkers-on-Hudson|year = 1923|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
* ''The Kingdom of the Mind'' published in 1927<ref name=":10">{{Cite book|title = The Kingdom of the Mind|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = Macmillan|year = 1927|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
* ''Creative Imagination: Studies in the psychology of literature''  published in 1929.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|title = Creative Imagination: Studies in the psychology of literature|last = Downey|first = June|publisher = Harcourt Brace|year = 1929|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref>

==Legacy==
A June Etta Downey Fund in Psychology was established by family members to support professorships, restore the June E. Downey Seminar Room, and support women in the Department of Psychology at the [[University of Wyoming]].<ref>{{cite news |work= Wyoming Tribune-Eagle |title= UW Panel Focuses on Legendary Professor |date= September 16, 1998 |accessdate= April 28, 2014 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-17924110.html |publisher= via HighBeam {{Subscription required}}}}</ref> She is also honored by the University of Wyoming, which is home to a bronze plaque with her name on it, the use of "Alma Mater" a song written by her, and has a building named after her.<ref>{{Cite web|title = June Etta Downey {{!}} Profiles {{!}} University of Wyoming|url = http://www.uwyo.edu/profiles/distinguished-leaders/june-etta-downey.html|website = www.uwyo.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref>

'''Michelle Drouin''' is an [[United States|American]] researcher who focuses on [[Social psychology|psychological issues]] dealing with [[social media]] and communications technology. She has studied deception during [[sexting]],<ref name="twsNYDailyNews"/> and how [[texting]] and sexting affect attachment in relationships between college students,<ref name="twsABCNews"/> as well as between adult relationships.<ref name="twsIndianaNewsCenter"/> She found correlations between coercive [[sexting]] and [[mental health]] problems<ref name="twsElsevier"/> as well as links between [[Internet troll]]ing and [[Sexual sadism disorder|sadism]].<ref name="twsLiveScience"/><ref name="tws21Alive"/> She described how people sometimes use social media to maintain ''back-burner relationships'' to keep alive connections to possible future romantic partners.<ref name="twsPsychologyToday2"/><ref name="twsHuffingtonPost"/> Much of her research focuses on social media sites such as [[Facebook]]; for example, she found that some people make new romantic connections by friending people on Facebook.<ref name="twsChicagoTribune"/> She studied the issue of [[Phantom vibration syndrome|phantom vibrations]] experienced by many cell phone users in which a phone seems to vibrate but doesn't; a study she conducted found that 89% of students experienced a phantom vibration at least once every two weeks.<ref name="twsPsychologyToday"/><ref name="twsPsychToday3"/> She found that people were more likely to experience phantom vibrations if they expected to react emotionally to incoming communications.<ref name="twsTheAtlantic"/> Her research found that young adults generally do not support the practice of employers using social media when making hiring decisions.<ref name="twsYoungstownNews"/> Drouin is associate professor of [[psychology]] at [[Indiana University – Purdue University Fort Wayne]].

'''Linda Fierz-David''' (1891–1955) was a [[Germans|German]] [[philologist]] and one of the first [[Analytical psychology|Jungian analyst]]s in [[Zurich]].<ref>Kirsch, Thomas B. ''The Jungians: A comparative and historical perspective. 1st edition. Philadelphia: Routledge, 2000. Print.''</ref> She was the first woman admitted in the [[University of Basel]], where she studied German philology.  She met Carl Jung in 1920, becoming one of his first pupils and closest friends.<ref name=atal>{{cite web|title=Linda Fierz David|url=http://www.atalantaweb.com/bio.php?id=28|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref>  She collected rare books and studied psychology, [[anthropology]], mythology and [[literature]].

In 2007, a critic writing for the Spanish newspaper El Pais described Fierz-David as “one of the most notable investigators of analytical psychiatry, one of the group of notable women who worked with Carl Gustav Jung in Zurich and were his disciples, and, according to the professor's wife (in a letter to Freud), “all, naturally, fell in love with him.”<ref name=elp>{{cite web| title =Una iniciación mistérica| work =El Pais Archivo| url =http://elpais.com/diario/2007/05/05/babelia/1178320631_850215.html }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Jung: A Feminist Revision by Susan Rowland | work =Polity| year =2001| url =http://www.polity.co.uk/content/BPL_Images/Content_store/Sample_chapter/0745625169%5CRowland.pdf}}</ref> Susan Rowland, an authority on Jung and his female acolytes, writes that “the Fierz family and the Jungs became friends” in the 1920s, and that “Jung travelled with the husband while analysing Linda on her unorthodox romantic situation: she was in love with both her husband and an Italian cousin.” Rowland notes that Fierz-David was nicknamed “Sieglinde” by Jung and that she “sought to remedy Jung’s inattention to the feminine perspective.”

==Other activities==
Fierz-David collected rare books and studied psychology, anthropology, mythology and literature. She was also involved in the Analytical Psychology Club of Zurich, of which she became head in 1928,<ref name=atal/>

==Works==
* ''The Dream of Poliphilo'':  The Soul in Love, New York: Pantheon Books, 1950. Translated by Mary Hottinger.<ref>{{cite web| title =Quadrant: The Journal of the C.G. Jung Foundation| work =CJ Jung Foundation | url =http://www.cgjungny.org/q/p/q21n2.html}}</ref> The book is a paraphrase and interpretation of the Hypnerotomachia, a fifteenth-century work by Francesco Colonna.<ref>{{cite web| last =Parker| first =Tyler| title =Jung's Emblems, the Poet's Enigmas| work =Poetry Magazine| date =Dec 1950| url =http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poetrymagazine/browse/77/3#!/20591460}}</ref>  Jung wrote the foreword.<ref>{{cite web| title =The Dream of Poliphilo. Translated by Mary Hottinger, interpreted by Linda Fierz-David, with a foreword by C. G. Jung| work =Wiley Online Library| url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1080/00049535108256055/abstract}}</ref>
* ''Villa of Mysteries'', 1957. This book, also published under the title Women's Dionysian Initiation: The Villa of Mysteries in Pompeii,<ref>{{cite web| title = Women's Dionysian Initiation: The Villa of Mysteries in Pompeii| work =B&B Smith Booksellers| url =http://www.bbsmith.com/?page=shop/flypage&product_id=23225}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =In the Footsteps| work =Aras.org| url =http://aras.org/docs/00038Singer.pdf }}</ref> is a Jungian analysis of the mystery chamber in the Roman city of Pompeii, whose frescos depict an initiation ceremony for women.<ref>{{cite web| title =Dreaming in Red | work =GoodReads| url =http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1074892.Dreaming_in_Red}}</ref> It was later published together with a text by Nor Hall under the title Dreaming in Red: The Women's Dionysian Initiation Chamber in Pompeii.<ref>{{cite web| title =Dreaming in red : the women's Dionysian initiation chamber in Pompeii / Linda Fierz-David, Nor Hall.| work =National Library of Australia | url =http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/30113318?q=isbn%3A9780882145518&c=book&versionId=36565566}}</ref>

A 2007 review of ''Villa of Mysteries'' for the Spanish newspaper El Pais emphasized that it is “not a work of philology or history” but rather a “very Jungian” volume that seems to interpret not just a particular set of frescoes in a particular city but to expand its analysis to all of Roman culture on the understanding that what happened in Pompeii also happened elsewhere in the Empire. Part of a “rich and colorful world of wealthy patrician houses and brothels,” the Villa of the Mysteries was a place where women were initiated into “the secret – and complex – rites of Bacchus and Ariadne, under the sign of Orpheus.” Fierz-David examines the way in which this initiation process involves the workings of the subconscious and the awareness of “the hidden and terrifying side of God,” and her interpretation, while “closely linked to Jungian psychoanalysis,” continually brings to bear a “very rich knowledge of classical mythology.”<ref name=elp/>

==Personal life==
Fierz-David was married to Hans Eduard Fierz (1882-1953),<ref name="The Jungians">{{Google books |plainurl= |id=8R3cUNra1d0C |page=16 |title=The Jungians: A Comparative and Historical Perspective }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Linda Fierz-David| work =Pomaska-Brand Verlag| url =http://www.pomaska-brand-verlag.de/index.php?id=122}}</ref> a Professor of Chemistry at the Technical University in Zurich and author of History of Chemistry (1945). Their son [[Markus Fierz]], born in 1912 in Basle, was a physicis. His twin brother Heinrich-Karl Fierz also studied with Jung, trained at the Burghölzli Mental Hospital in Zurich under H. W. Maier and Manfred Bleuler, and wrote his doctoral dissertation on electroshock therapy. The younger Fierz worked as a psychiatrist at the Binswanger Clinic, Sanatorium Bellevue, and in 1964 co-founded the Klinik am Zürichberg, serving as its first medical director.<ref name="The Jungians" /><ref>{{cite web| title =Jungian Psychiatry | work =Daimon Publishers| url =http://www.daimon.ch/3856305211_2I.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Heinrich-Karl Fierz| work =Daimon Publishers | url =http://www.daimon.ch/catalog/advanced_search_result.php?keywords=Heinrich-Karl%20Fierz}}</ref>

She has received a number of awards, including the 2012 Distinguished Scientific Achievement Award in Psychology and the Monette-Horwitz Trust Award in 2001. == Career== In 1982, Franklin received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in journalism from [[San Francisco State University]], and at one point she worked as a legal affairs news reporter.{{cite web | title = Karen Franklin | year = 2015 | work = Alliant International University | accessdate = 27 October 2015 | url = http://www.alliant.edu/advanced-search/faculty-profile.php?profile_no=731}} She received her [[PhD]] in 1997 from the [[California School of Professional Psychology]]. She is an instructor of clinical psychology at [[Alliant International University]], and serves as chair of the Ethics & Professional Affairs Committee of the Alameda County Psychological Association. Franklin formerly worked as a [[criminal investigator]] for [[death penalty]] cases, which sparked her interest in [[forensic psychology]].{{cite book | authors = Brown R, Davenport J | year = 2011 | title = Forensic Science: Advanced Investigations | publisher = South-Western Educational Pub | isbn = 0538450894 | url = http://www.karenfranklin.com/slider-1-test/profile-in-forensic-science-textbook/}} In her forensic psychology practice, she conducts [[Competency evaluation (law)|competency evaluation]]s, risk assessment, and [[Mental status examination|mental state exam]]s for criminal defendants, particularly [[sex offender]]s as well as defendants facing possible execution.2014, The Guardian, [http://www.theguardian.com/profile/karen-franklin Karen Franklin], Accessed July 26, 2014, "...Karen Franklin is an award-winning researcher, professor and forensic psychologist in the San Francisco Bay area ... evaluation of criminal defendants.." [[File:Maria-Galindo.jpg|thumbnail|150px|María Galindo]]
'''María Galindo''' (born 1964) is a Bolivian [[anarcha-feminism|anarcha-feminist]], lesbian activist, and psychologist. She has worked as a radio presenter and television host. She has written three books and is also a screenwriter. Although not well-known outside her country, Galindo is a controversial person in Bolivia.

Born in [[Cochabamba]]<ref name=Santoro2010>{{cite web|last1=Santoro|first1=Sonia|title=MARIA GALINDO: EL CUERPO EN LA CALLE|url=http://www.soniasantoro.com/index.php/articulos/articulos-de-la-autora/item/maria-galindo-el-cuerpo-en-la-calle|publisher=Sonia Santoro|accessdate=1 February 2015|language=Spanish|date=9 December 2010}}</ref> (another source says [[La Paz]]) to an upper-middle-class family,<ref name=lostiempos.com2012>{{cite news|title=María Galindo: Mujer es igual a rebeldía|url=http://www.lostiempos.com/lecturas/varios/varios/20120708/maria-galindo-mujer-es-igual-a-rebeldia_177703_375235.html|accessdate=1 February 2015|publisher=''Los Tiempos''|date=8 July 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref> she left Bolivia with a visa as a nun to study at a [[Holy See|Vatican]] university.<ref name=Santoro2010 /> She returned in 1992, and on March 8, she co-founded [[Mujeres Creando]] ("Women Creating"), a Bolivian collective and social movement which confront sexism and homophobia. She broadcasts a regular radio program from ''Mujeres Creando''.<ref name=GreenLackowski2012>{{cite web|first1=Sharyl|last1=Green|first2=Peter|last2=Lackowski|title=Bolivian Radical Feminist Maria Galindo on Evo Morales, Sex-Ed, and Rebellion in the Universe of Women|url=http://upsidedownworld.org/main/bolivia-archives-31/3549--bolivian-radical-feminist-maria-galindo-on-evo-morales-sex-ed-and-rebellion-in-the-universe-of-women-|publisher=Upside Down World|accessdate=1 February 2015|date=2 April 2012}}</ref> For her controversial actions (often labeled as [[Visual arts by indigenous peoples of the Americas#Performance art|performance art]] or [[street theater]]), she was arrested and assaulted several times by Bolivian police even though her older brother, [[José Antonio Galindo Neder]], was a minister under former president [[Carlos Mesa]]. She also champions the rights of women who are victims of abuse and sexual harassment caused by [[machismo]]. Gallindo, a psychologist, teaches sociology at [[Higher University of San Andrés]].<ref name=lostiempos.com2012 /> She states, "The street is the most important political setting... So we took the street and made the graffiti that we continue to make in four cities in the country. With graffiti we try to mix different topics simultaneously."<ref name="Dangl2007">{{cite book|last=Dangl|first=Benjamin|title=The Price of Fire: Resource Wars and Social Movements in Bolivia|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ApoOmLFwWDMC&pg=PA167|year=2007|publisher=AK Press|isbn=978-1-904859-33-8|pages=167–}}</ref> Galindo is an atheist.<ref name=lostiempos.com2012 />

==Selected works==

* 2007, ''Ninguna mujer nace para puta (with Sonia Sánchez), ISBN 978-987-21900-3-3
* 2004, ''Archivo Cordero 1900 - 1961

'''Michele J. Gelfand''' is a [[Cultural psychology|cultural psychologist]], best known for being an expert on tightness-looseness theory,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/culture-conscious/201306/some-it-tight-some-it-loose|title=Some Like It Tight, Some Like It Loose|last=White|first=Lawrence T.|last2=Jackson|first2=Steven|date=2013-07-21|website=Psychology Today|access-date=2016-06-01}}</ref> which explains variations in the strength of social [[Norm (social)|norms]] and punishments across human groups.<ref name=":2" /> She is currently a Professor and Distinguished University Scholar Teacher at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gelfand.umd.edu/pages/People4.html|title=Michele J. Gelfand|website=University of Maryland Department of Psychology|access-date=2016-05-31}}</ref>

== Education and career  ==

Gelfand studied at [[Colgate University]], where she graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in psychology in 1989. She graduated from the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign]] in 1996 with a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in [[social psychology]] and [[Industrial and organizational psychology|organizational psychology]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gelfand.umd.edu/Gelfand%20vita%20Oct%202014.pdf|title=Michele J. Gelfand Curriculum Vitae|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Maryland Department of Psychology|publisher=|access-date=2016-05-31}}</ref> There, she studied under the mentorship of Harry Triandis, one of the founders of cross-cultural psychology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/international/pi/2013/03/collaborate.aspx|title=Multinational collaborations in culture and psychology|last=Gelfand|first=Michele J.|date=March 2013|website=Psychology International|publisher=American Psychological Association|access-date=2016-06-01}}</ref> She was on the faculty of [[New York University]] from 1995 to 1996, and she has worked at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]] since 1996.<ref name=":0" />

Gelfand is the editor of several [[Academic publishing|academic books]] and series, including ''Advances in Culture and Psychology'', which she co-founded; ''Psychology of Conflict and Conflict Management in Organizations''; and ''The Handbook of Negotiation and Culture''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://academicminute.org/2014/11/michele-gelfand-university-of-maryland-american-regionalism/|title=American Regionalism|date=2014-11-04|website=The Academic Minute|publisher=WAMC Northeast Public Radio|access-date=2016-06-01}}</ref> She was the president of the International Association for Conflict Management from 2009 to 2010.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asfee.fr/?q=node/237|title=24th Annual Conference of the International Association for Conflict Management|website=Association Française d'Economie Expérimentale|access-date=2016-06-01}}</ref>

== Research ==
Gelfand has conducted research across many cultures, using field, experimental, computational, and neuroscientific methods to understand the evolution of cultural differences and their consequences for individuals, teams, organizations, and nations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gelfand.umd.edu/pages/Research.html|title=Research: Culture and Psychology|website=Michele F. Gelfand|publisher=University of Maryland Department of Psychology|access-date=2016-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gelfand|first=M. J.|last2=Erez|first2=M.|last3=Aycan|first3=Z.|date=2007|title=Cross-cultural organizational behavior|url=http://gelfand.umd.edu/pages/papers/Gelfandetal2007.pdf|journal=Annual Review of Psychology|volume=58|pages=479–514|doi=10.1146/annurev.psych.58.110405.085559|pmid=17044797|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> Gelfand has also done work on the role of culture in [[negotiation]] and conflict and the psychology of revenge and forgiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gelfand|first=M. J.|last2=Leslie|first2=L.|last3=Keller|first3=K.|last4=De Dreu|first4=C.|date=2012|title=Conflict cultures in organizations: How leaders shape conflict cultures and their organization-level consequences|url=http://gelfand.umd.edu/papers/Gelfand%20et%20al%20(2012)b%20Conflict%20cultures.pdf|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|volume=97|issue=6|pages=1131|doi=10.1037/a0029993|pmid=23025807|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gelfand|first=M. J.|last2=Severance|first2=L.|last3=Lee|first3=T.|last4=Bruss|first4=C. B.|last5=et al.|date=2015|title=Getting to Yes: The linguistic signature of the deal in the U.S. and Egypt|url=|journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior|volume=36|issue=7|pages=967|doi=10.1002/job.2026|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zheng|first=Xue|last2=Fehr|first2=Ryan|last3=Tai|first3=Kenneth|last4=Narayanan|first4=Jayanth|last5=Gelfand|first5=Michele J.|date=2014|title=The Unburdening Effects of Forgiveness: Effects on Slant Perception and Jumping Height|url=http://www.gelfand.umd.edu/Social%20Psychological%20and%20Personality%20Science-2014-Zheng-1948550614564222.pdf|journal=Social Psychological and Personality Science|publisher=University of California, Davis|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>

=== Cultural tightness-looseness ===
Gelfand is considered a pioneering researcher on the concept of tightness-looseness.<ref name=":1" /> She is credited with defining the tightness-looseness classification system, which assesses how much a culture adheres to social norms and tolerates deviance. Tight cultures are more restrictive, with stricter disciplinary measures for norm violations while loose cultures have weaker social norms and a higher tolerance for deviant behavior. Gelfand found that a history of threats, such as natural disasters, high population density, or vulnerability to infectious diseases, is associated with greater tightness. Her research has shown that tightness allows cultures to coordinate more effectively to survive threats.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Gelfand|first=Michele J.|last2=Raver|first2=Jana L.|last3=Nishii|first3=Lisa|last4=Leslie|first4=Lisa M.|last5=Lun|first5=Janetta|last6=Lim|first6=Beng Chong|last7=et al|date=2011-05-27|title=Differences Between Tight and Loose Cultures: A 33-Nation Study|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/332/6033/1100|journal=Science|language=en|volume=332|issue=6033|pages=1100–1104|doi=10.1126/science.1197754|issn=0036-8075|pmid=21617077|bibcode=2011Sci...332.1100G}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harrington|first=Jesse R.|last2=Gelfand|first2=Michele J.|date=2014|title=Tightness–looseness across the 50 united states|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/111/22/7990.full.pdf|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>

'''Linda Susanne Gottfredson''' (née '''Howarth'''; born June 24, 1947) is a professor of [[educational psychology]] at the [[University of Delaware]] and co-director of the Delaware-[[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]] Project for the Study of [[Intelligence quotient|Intelligence]] and Society. Gottfredson's work has been influential in shaping U.S. public and private policies regarding [[affirmative action]], hiring quotas, and "[[Race (classification of human beings)|race]]-norming" on aptitude tests.

She is on the boards of the [[International Society for the Study of Individual Differences]] (ISSID), the [[International Society for Intelligence Research]] (ISIR), and the editorial boards of the scientific journals ''[[Intelligence (journal)|Intelligence]]'', ''[[Learning and Individual Differences]]'', and ''[[Society (journal)|Society]]''. Gottfredson has received research grants worth $267,000 from the [[Pioneer Fund]].<ref name="ReferenceA">''U. Delaware Reaches Accord On Race Studies'' By Ron Kaufman The Scientist 6[14]:1, Jul. 06, 1992</ref><ref>''The Pioneer Fund: Bankrolling the Professors of Hate''Adam Miller The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education, No. 6 (Winter, 1994-1995), pp. 58-61</ref>

== Life and work ==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Two Curve Bell with Jobs.jpg|thumb|440px|These are idealized [[Normal distribution|normal curves]] comparing the IQs of [[Black people|Blacks]] and [[White people|Whites]] in the US in 1981. Source: [http://www.udel.edu/educ/gottfredson/reprints/2004socialconsequences.pdf Social Consequences] by Gottfredson. Labels show Gottefredson's expectations for job and life potential for people of different intelligence levels.]]  -->

Born in [[San Francisco]], she and her first husband Gary Don Gottfredson received bachelor's degrees in psychology in 1969 from [[University of California, Berkeley]], then worked in the [[Peace Corps]] in [[Malaysia]] until 1972. She also taught in schools for the disadvantaged for a time when she was young.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0765804972&id=VLtTKixjfYQC&pg=PA97&]</ref> They both went to graduate school at [[Johns Hopkins University]], where she received a Ph.D. in sociology in 1977.

Gottfredson took a position at Hopkins' Center for Social Organization of Schools and investigated issues of occupational segregation and typology based on skill sets and intellectual capacity. She married [[Robert A. Gordon]], who worked in a related area at Hopkins, and they divorced by the mid-90s.<ref>[http://www.jhu.edu/~gazette/1994/nov2894/gordon.html]</ref>

In 1985, Gottfredson participated in a conference called "The [[General intelligence factor|g Factor]] in Employment Testing." The papers presented were published in the December 1986 issue of the ''Journal of Vocational Behavior'', which she edited. In 1986, Gottfredson was appointed Associate Professor of Educational Studies at the [[University of Delaware]], Newark.

That year, she presented a series of papers on general intelligence factor and employment. Gottfredson has said "We now have out there what I call the egalitarian fiction that all groups are equal in intelligence. We have social policy based on that fiction. For example, the [[1991 Civil Rights Act]] codified ''Griggs vs. Duke Power'', which said that if you have disproportionate hiring by race, you are prima facie -- that's prima facie evidence of racial discrimination. ...Differences in intelligence have real world effects, whether we think they're there or not, whether we want to wish them away or not. And we don't do anybody any good, certainly not the low-IQ people, by denying that those problems exist..."<ref>[http://aad.english.ucsb.edu/docs/PBS-oct94.htm "Race, IQ, Success and Charles Murray"]</ref>

She was promoted to full professor at the University of Delaware in 1990.

Gottfredson's research and views have stirred considerable controversy, especially her testimony on public affirmative action policy and her defense of ''[[The Bell Curve]],'' especially ''[[Mainstream Science on Intelligence]]'', a statement she wrote, which was signed by 51 colleagues and published in the ''[[The Wall Street Journal]].''<ref name="gottfredson">Gottfredson, Linda (December 13, 1994). [[Mainstream Science on Intelligence]]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', p A18.</ref> Since then she has written a number of articles on [[race and intelligence]], especially as it applies to occupational qualification.

==Criticism==
According to sociocultural anthropologist [[Francisco Gil-White]], in publishing studies financed by the Pioneer Fund, Linda Gottfredson is part of a concerted effort to legitimize racist ideology through pseudo-science, together with an assortment of other people with inadequate or completely missing scientific qualifications for studying human intelligence:
<small>
:''suspicion naturally grows when one finds that Pioneer Fund recipients have only one thing in common: they attack blacks''
:[...]
:''The outspoken Linda Gottfredson once again is neither a psychologist nor a biologist, but a sociologist who teaches in the Department of Education at the University of Delaware. So we have a physicist, a philosopher, and a sociologist. What do they have in common with the IQ-testers? Other than that they attack blacks from their academic perches and collect their rewards from the Pioneer Fund, nothing.''<ref>http://www.hirhome.com/rr/rrchap11.htm</ref></small>

[[Barry Mehler]] writes in ''The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education'' that Gottfredson is attempting to promote racial theories used by the [[Nazis]]:
<small>
:''Thus we see that Gottfredson's opposition to affirmative action is based not in any such claimed "objectivity", but in a sanitized resurrection of ideas put forward by Nazi racial theorists. Under the false pretense of intellectual honesty, she has endorsed the same poisonous ideology that half a century ago led to the Holocaust.''<ref>Mehler 1994</ref></small>

According to the website ''Tracking the Alternative Right'':
<small>
:''Linda Gottfredson joined Stefan Molyneux for the December 29 broadcast of Freedomain Radio, entitled "Race, Evolution and Intelligence." Using recycled claims from''The Bell Curve'' — a notorious book by Richard Herrnstein (1930–1994) and Charles Murray — Molyneux asserted that there is a racial hierarchy as far as IQ distribution is concerned.
:[...]
:''Gottfredson, a professor of educational psychology at the University of Delaware, agreed, noting that Molyneux neglected to mention one final racial category. "I would just add one more group, um, and that's African blacks. Um, the IQs of different, uh, groups of African blacks, you know, range more around 70." Gottfredson, of course, has accepted $267,000 in research grants by the racist Pioneer Fund since 1988, and was a staunch opponent of the 1991 Civil Rights Act.''<ref>[https://hailtothegynocracy.wordpress.com/2016/01/02/stefan-molyneux-and-linda-gottfredson-promote-scientific-racism/]</ref></small>

{{Infobox scholar |name = Tsuruko Haraguchi |image = Tsuruko Haraguchi, circa 1910.PNG |image_size = |caption = Haraguchi, {{circa|1909}} |birth_name = Tsuru Arai |birth_date = 18 June 1886 |birth_place = [[Tomioka, Gunma]], [[Japan]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1915|9|26|1886|6|18|df=y}} |death_place = |education = Takasaki Women's High School |alma_mater = [[Japan Women's University]],
[[Teachers College, Columbia University]] |thesis_title = Mental Fatigue |thesis_year = 1912 |main_interests = psychology |influences = Matsumoto Matataro, Edward Thorndike, Robert S. Woodworth, James McKeen Cattell }} {{nihongo|'''Tsuruko Haraguchi'''|原口鶴子||18 June 1886 – 26 September 1915|lead=yes}} was a Japanese [[psychologist]] and the first Japanese woman to receive a [[Doctor of Philosophy]]. ==Life and career== Haraguchi was born {{nihongo|'''Tsuru Arai'''|洗鶴}} in [[Tomioka, Gunma|Tomioka]] in 1886. Her father was a wealthy farmer and she had two sisters. She attended Takasaki Women's High School, graduating in 1902, two years earlier than her classmates of the same age.{{cite web|url=http://www.apadivisions.org/division-35/about/heritage/tsuruko-haraguchi-biography.aspx|title=Tsuruko Haraguchi (1886 - 1915)|first=Miki|last=Takasuna|publisher=[[American Psychological Association]] Society for the Psychology of Women|accessdate=8 November 2015}} She enrolled at [[Japan Women's University]] in 1903 to study humanities in the Faculty of English Literature. At the time, women were not allowed to earn graduate degrees or beyond at Japanese universities, and higher educational institutions for women were not yet officially recognized.{{cite web|url=http://www.feministvoices.com/tsuruko-haraguchi/|title=Tsuruko Haraguchi|year=2013|first=Amanda|last=Jenkins|work=Psychology's Feminist Voices|accessdate=8 November 2015}} Thus, when her mentor, the psychologist [[Matsumoto Matataro]], encouraged her to pursue further education, she left Japan for the United States after graduating in 1906. ===Studies at Columbia University=== She entered the [[Teachers College, Columbia University|Teachers College of Columbia University]] in 1907 to complete a doctorate in psychology. She focused on experimental psychology and pedagogy, and was taught by [[Edward Thorndike]], [[Robert S. Woodworth]] and [[James McKeen Cattell]].{{cite web|url=http://psychology.okstate.edu/museum/japanese/g-h.html|title=Japanese Psychologists: G–H|work=A Brief Guide to the History of Japanese Psychology|publisher=Oklahoma State Psychology Museum|accessdate=8 November 2015}} She completed her thesis, titled "Mental Fatigue", in 1912, based on experiments on herself in which she multiplied four-digit numbers and translated sentences of [[John Dewey]]'s writing. She received her doctorate on 5 June 1912, becoming the first Japanese woman to attain a PhD in any field. She was married that same day. ===Later life in Japan=== Haraguchi returned to Japan, where she expanded her doctoral thesis and translated it into Japanese. It was published under the title ''Studies on Mental Work and Fatigue'' in 1914. She lectured at Japan Women's University occasionally and was involved in the establishment of an experimental psychology laboratory at the university. She also wrote a memoir, ''Tanoshiki omohide'', "Pleasant memoirs", in 1915, in which she drew from her experiences studying at Columbia University to advocate for women's education and value.{{cite journal|last1=Patessio|first1=Mara|title=Women getting a ‘university’ education in Meiji Japan: discourses, realities, and individual lives.|journal=Japan Forum|date=Dec 2013|volume=25|issue=4|pages=556–581|doi=10.1080/09555803.2013.788053|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=92664352&site=ehost-live|accessdate=23 December 2015|issn=0955-5803|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}} ==Personal life== Haraguchi married Takejirō Haraguchi, a [[Waseda University]] professor,{{cite book|last=Mulhern|first=Chieko Irie|title=Heroic with Grace: Legendary Women of Japan|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hCk5k9RSnb4C&pg=PA214|year=1991|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-0-7656-3265-4|page=214}} on 5 June 1912. They had a son and daughter. ==Death and legacy== Haraguchi died of [[tuberculosis]] on September 26, 1915, at age 29. Her last work, a Japanese translation of [[Francis Galton]]'s ''Hereditary Genius'' (first published in 1869), was published posthumously in 1915. A record of her experiences at Columbia University and her observations of cultural differences between Japan and the U.S., ''Happy Memories'', was also published in 1915. Two documentaries have been produced about Haraguchi's life and work: ''The Life of Tsuruko Haraguchi'' (2007) and ''Psychologist Tsuruko Haraguchi: Memories of Her Days at Columbia University in the Early 1900s'' (2008). ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haraguchi, Tsuruko}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese psychologists]] [[Category:Women psychologists]] [[Category:Japanese women writers]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]] [[Category:People from Gunma Prefecture]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Japanese translators]] [[Category:English–Japanese translators]] [[Category:20th-century deaths from tuberculosis]] [[Category:20th-century women writers]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}

<ref name="MD Page">{{cite web|title=Professional Summary|url=http://www.harrison-ross.yourmd.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/site.physicians/action/dtl/phys/99848609.cfm|website=Phyllis Harrison-Ross, MD|publisher=MedFusion|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref>'''Phyllis Harrison-Ross''' (born 1936) is an American psychiatrist who pioneered programs for developmentally disabled and mentally ill children.<ref name=Wayne/>

==Education==
She received her B.S. from [[Albion College]] in 1956 and her M.D. from [[Wayne State University School of Medicine]] in 1959. She completed her fellowship at the [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]] from 1964-1966.<ref name=Wayne/>

==Career==
She instructed at several institutions including [[Cornell Medical School]] and [[New York Medical College]]. She has sat on the Medical Review Board of the New York State Commission of Corrections several times and has been the chair since 2008. She served as director and chief of psychiatry at Metropolitan Hospital Community Health Center. She is also a member of the [[American Psychiatric Association]] and [[Black Psychiatrists of America]], and was president of the latter from 1976-1978.<ref name="MD Page" /><ref name=Wayne>{{cite book|last1=Wayne|first1=Tiffany K.|title=American women of science since 1900|date=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, Calif.|isbn=9781598841589|pages=490–491}}</ref>

==Legacy==
She was the first in her field to start programs for children with developmental disabilities and mental illnesses. Her programs were implemented in public schools and reduced the institutionalization of children. She also studies the effects of poverty on children and treated children for phobias. In the 1970s, she hosted a talk show and co-hosted a radio show that educated parents. After 9/11, the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] attack, and [[Hurricane Katrina]], she helped victims recover from disaster-induced mental illness.<ref name=Wayne/>

==Awards==
She received the Leadership in Medicine Award of the Susan Smith McKinney Stewart Society in 1978, the Award of Merit of the Public Health Association of New York City in 1980, and the Solomon Carter Fuller Award of the American Psychiatric Association in 2004.<ref name=Wayne/>

}}'''Molly Harrower''' (born '''Mary Rachel Harrower'''; January 25, 1906 – February 20, 1999) was an American [[clinical psychology|clinical psychologist]]. During the Second World War she created a large-scale multiple choice [[Rorschach test]]. She was one of the first clinical psychologists to open a private practice. Specializing in diagnostics, Harrower developed a scale allowing practitioners to predict which patients would profit from [[psychotherapy]].

==Family and early life==
Molly Harrower was born in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa, the daughter of James, a banker, and Ina (née White) Harrower.<ref name=Pickren>{{Cite encyclopedia| last = Pickren| first = Wade| title = Profile of Molly Harrower| accessdate=30 December 2015|encyclopedia = Psychology's Feminist Voices Multimedia Internet Archive| url=http://www.feministvoices.com/molly-harrower/|date = 2010}}</ref> Her Scottish-born parents were visiting South Africa when she was born and the family returned to the United Kingdom while she was an infant.<ref name=oralhistory>{{Cite interview| interviewer = Emily Ring| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = University of Florida Oral History Project| date = 26 November 1982| accessdate=30 December 2015|url = http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00006059/00001}}</ref>{{rp|2}} Their home was in [[Cheam]], a village south of London.<ref name=DewsburyAPA>{{Cite web| last = Dewsbury| first = Donald A.| title = Molly Harrower (1906-1999)| work = American Psychological Association| accessdate = 30 December 2015| date = 1999| url = http://www.apadivisions.org/division-35/about/heritage/molly-harrower-biography.aspx}}</ref> Molly Harrower had one brother, who was three years younger. From the age of ten she attended the [[Godolphin School]] in [[Salisbury]] where she excelled at sports, particularly [[cricket]].<ref name=oralhistory />{{rp|3}}

==Education==
After leaving the Godolphin School Harrower was sent to a [[finishing school]] in Paris. She was unhappy with the school environment so her parents sent her to live with a family while learning French in Switzerland for a year. <ref name=oralhistory />{{rp|6}}

In 1925, with the help of a family friend, she was admitted to [[Bedford College (London)|Bedford College]]'s [[journalism]] program despite having no academic qualifications. After auditing a psychology course taught by [[Beatrice Edgell]], who became a mentor to her, Harrower switched to a program leading to an academic diploma in psychology. She did not complete the three-year program, being forced to leave after two years because of her family's financial difficulties.<ref name=ValentineEdgell>{{Cite book| publisher = Nova Science Publishers| isbn = 9781594543890| last = Valentine| first = Elizabeth R.| title = Beatrice Edgell: pioneer woman psychologist| location = New York| date = 2006}}</ref>{{rp|56}} She then spent four months in France on a scholarship to study painting and dancing before returning to England, where she worked as an assistant to [[Charles Kay Ogden|C.K. Ogden]], mainly in his capacity as a book dealer in [[Cambridge]].<ref name=Krawiec>{{Cite book| publisher = Clinical Psychology Publishing Co.| volume = 3| pages = 85–104| editors = T.S. Krawiek (ed.)| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = The Psychologists: Autobiographies of Distinguished Living Psychologists| chapter = Changing horses in mid-stream: an experimentalist becomes a clinician| location = Brandon, Vermont| date = 1978}}</ref>{{rp|89}} 

Ogden recommended her to his friend the [[Gestalt theory|Gestalt psychologist]] [[Kurt Koffka]], who directed the psychology laboratory at [[Smith College]] in [[Massachusetts]].<ref name=ValentineEdgell />{{rp|56}} Smith College granted her a fellowship and she began working with Koffka in 1928.<ref name=Pickren /> On the invitation of Beatrice Edgell she returned to Bedford College in 1932 as a temporary senior lecturer, filling in for one year after the accidental death of her former teacher Victoria Hazlitt. Under Koffka's supervision she earned a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1934 for a [[thesis|dissertation]] entitled ''Organization in Higher Mental Processes''. Hers was the first psychology doctorate awarded by Smith College.<ref name=AmPsychobit>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.55.9.1058| volume = 55| issue = 9| page = 1058| last = Dewsbury| first = Donald A.| title = Molly R. Harrower (1906–1999)| journal = American Psychologist| date = September 2000}}</ref> The external examiners were [[George Humphrey (psychologist)|George Humphrey]], [[Edwin Boring]], and [[Arnold Gesell]].<ref name=ValentineEdgell />{{rp|57}}

==Career==

===Research===
Harrower became interested in clinical psychology when she observed major changes in a friend's personality after surgery.<ref name=DewsburyAPA /> The [[Rockefeller Foundation]] granted her a three-year post-doctoral fellowship, which she took up in 1937, to study "the psychological effects of surgical operations, the impact of surgical shock" at the [[Montreal Neurological Institute]] (MNI). In order to become familiar with the hospital setting she first spent six months working with [[Kurt Goldstein]] at the [[Montefiore Medical Center|Montefiore Hospital]] in New York.<ref name=Krawiec />{{rp|89}}  At the MNI she worked with [[Wilder Penfield]], and was involved as a psychologist in the pioneering [[Wilder Penfield#neural stimulation|neural stimulation]] studies that led to the development of the [[Montreal procedure]] for treating epilepsy.<ref name=Pickren /> 

Early in the Second World War, Harrower received a grant from the Canadian [[National Research Council (Canada)|National Research Council]] to develop a large-scale [[Rorschach test]]. <ref name=Krawiec />{{rp|90}} The group test was used to screen military recruits based on their responses when shown a standard series of inkblot designs. The subjects were given a list of possible interpretations from which to choose and a high number of "neurotic" choices was seen as necessitating a "psychiatric check-up".<ref name=Eysenck>{{cite book|last1=Eysenck|first1=Hans|authorlink1=Hans Eysenck|title=Dimensions of Personality|date=1998|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, NJ|isbn=1-56000-985-3|page=213|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=yetzyOzYl-4C&pg=PA213|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> This allowed the Rorschach to be given to large groups in as little as 15 minutes, in comparison to the normally administered Rorschach that could take an hour per individual.<ref>Harrower-Erickson, M. R., & Steiner, M. E. (1945). Large scale Rorschach techniques: A manual for the group Rorschach and Multiple Choice Test.</ref> The Multiple Choice Rorschach attracted a flurry of attention in the few years after. The test was ultimately found to be of little value, though.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Engle | first1 = T. L. | year = 1946 | title = The use of the Harrower-Erickson Multiple Choice (Rorschach) Test in differentiating between well-adjusted and maladjusted high-school pupils | url = | journal = Journal of Educational Psychology | volume = 37 | issue = 9| pages = 550–556 | doi=10.1037/h0057278}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jensen | first1 = M. B. | last2 = Rotter | first2 = J. B. | year = 1945 | title = The validity of the Multiple Choice Rorschach Test in officer candidate selection | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 42 | issue = 3| pages = 182–185 | doi=10.1037/h0058540}}</ref>

In 1941 Harrower moved from Montreal to [[Madison, Wisconsin]] where her husband, neurosurgeon Theodore Erickson, had obtained a position at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] medical school.<ref name=Pickren /> She received funding from the [[Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation|Macy Foundation]] to continue developing and training psychologists in the use of large-scale Rorschach tests. She also worked as a consultant to the United States Army and Air Force as well as the [[United States Department of State]].<ref name=Krawiec />{{rp|91}}

===Clinical practice===
Harrower opened a private practice in New York City in 1945, one of the first clinical psychologists to do so. She specialized in psychodiagnostic testing of medical patients referred to her by psychiatrists, neurologists and other physicians, using the Rorschach test as her primary tool.<ref name=Pickren /> During the course of her practice she used her diagnostic techniques on over 1,600 patients, keeping records of each consultation, and followed up with the treating therapists to develop a scale predicting the likelihood of successful therapy. The result was published in 1965 in ''Psychodiagnostic Testing: An Empirical Approach''.<ref name=AmPsychobit /><ref name=Psyctestemp>{{Cite book| publisher = Charles C. Thomas| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = Psychodiagnostic Testing: An Empirical Approach| date = 1965}}</ref>

After undergoing psychoanalysis herself from 1944 to 1946 she extended her practice to include psychotherapy.<ref name=oralhistory />{{rp|10}} Among her innovative techniques was poetry therapy, about which she published a book, ''The Therapy of Poetry'', in 1972.<ref name=Mazza>{{Cite book| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 9781135391911| last = Mazza| first = Nicholas| title = Poetry Therapy: Theory and Practice| url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=AdsiRrVGHk4C&page=PA8|date = 2013}}</ref>{{rp|8}} <ref name=therpoet>{{Cite book| publisher = C. C. Thomas| isbn = 9780398023119| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = The Therapy of Poetry| date = 1972}}</ref> She also did consulting work for organizations such as the Children’s Court of Manhattan, the [[National Multiple Sclerosis Society]], and the [[Unitarian Universalism|Unitarian-Universalist Church]].<ref name=DewsburyAPA /> She taught at the [[New School|New School for Social Research]] from 1963 to 1968. <ref name=AmPsychobit /> 

Harrower was president of the New York Society of Clinical Psychologists in 1952-53.<ref name=AmPsychobit /> She worked on the development of a certification program for New York State psychologists.<ref name=DewsburyAPA />

===University of Florida===
Harrower left New York and  joined the faculty of the [[University of Florida]] in [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]] in 1967, teaching clinical psychology. She retired  at the age of 70 and was named an emeritus professor in 1975.<ref name=About>{{cite web|title=About: History and setting|url=http://neuropsy.phhp.ufl.edu/about.html|website=Neuropsychology|publisher=University of Florida|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref> In 1972 she was awarded the [[Bruno Klopfer Award]] by the [[Society for Personality Assessment]].<ref name=SPA>{{cite web|title=SPA Awards|url=http://www.personality.org/about/awards/|website=Society for Personality Assessment|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref> The University of Florida made her an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] in March 1981. <ref name=hondeg>{{cite web|title=Honorary Degree Recipients|url=http://president.ufl.edu/office/honors-awards/honorary-degree-recipients/|publisher=University of Florida|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref> She established the Molly Harrower Women's Golf Endowment at the University of Florida.<ref>{{cite web|title=Molly Harrower Women's Golf Endowment|url=http://www.uff.ufl.edu/scholarships/ScholarshipInfo.asp?ScholarshipFund=008071|publisher=University of Florida Foundation|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref>

===Publications===
Harrower's publications include 20 books and more than 100 articles and book chapters.<ref name=ValentineEdgell />{{rp|58}} Among these were four books of poetry, the first of which, ''Plain Jane'', was a book of children's poems published in 1929.<ref name=Krawiec />{{rp|101}} In 1983 she published a selection of her correspondence with Kurt Koffka dating from 1930 until his death in 1941.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = University Presses of Florida| isbn = 9780813007601| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = Kurt Koffka, An Unwitting Self-portrait| date = 1983}}</ref>

In 1976 Harrower published a notable article based on the examination of records of Rorschach tests administered to Nazi war criminals immediately after the Second World War. She found that they did not show any common personality type, and that some appeared to be psychologically normal. Based on this conclusion, she cautioned that "well-integrated, productive and secure personalities are no protection against being sucked into a vortex of myth and deception, which may ultimately erupt into the commitment of horror on a grand scale".<ref name=nazi>{{Cite journal| volume = 40| issue = 4| pages = 341–351| last = Harrower| first = Molly| title = Rorschach records of the Nazi war criminals: an experimental study after thirty years| journal = Journal of Personality Assessment| date = August 1976| doi=10.1207/s15327752jpa4004_1}}</ref> This research led to her collaboration on a book published in 1995 entitled ''The Quest for the Nazi Personality: A Psychological Investigation of Nazi War Criminals''. <ref name=nazibook>{{Cite book| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 9781317843733| last1 = Zillmer| first1 = Eric A.| last2 = Harrower| first2 = Molly| last3 = Ritzler| first3 = Barry A.| last4 = Archer| first4 = Robert P.| title = The Quest for the Nazi Personality: A Psychological Investigation of Nazi War Criminals| date=2013|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=mTzjAQAAQBAJ}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Molly Harrower was married twice and had no children. Her first husband was Theodore Erickson, a neurosurgeon whom she met while working at the Montreal Neurological Institute. They were married in 1938 and were divorced in 1944. During their marriage she published under the name Harrower-Erickson. She married Mortimer Lahm, a businessman, in 1955. Lahm died in 1967. <ref name=Pickren />

After her retirement Harrower continued to live in Gainesville. She died at home on 20 February 1999.<ref name=NYTobit>{{Cite news| last = Saxon| first = Wolfgang| title = Molly Harrower, 93, expert on Rorschach test| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 1 January 2016| date = 28 February 1999| url = http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/28/us/molly-harrower-93-expert-on-rorschach-test.html}}</ref> 

==Partial bibliography==

* 1983, "Kurt Koffka: an unwitting self-portrait." Gainesville, FL: University of Florida Press.
* 1991, "Inkblots and poems." In C. E. Walker (Ed.) The history of clinical psychology in autobiography Vol. 1 (pp. 125–169).  Pacific Grove, CA: Brooks/Cole.

{{Orphan|date=October 2014}}

'''Helen Elizabeth Haste''' (born March 17, 1943) is a [[social psychology|social]], [[developmental psychology|developmental]], and [[cultural psychology|cultural psychologist]] and a writer and broadcaster. She is a [[visiting professor]] in the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]].<ref name="Harvard bio">{{cite web | url=http://www.gse.harvard.edu/directory/faculty/faculty-detail/?fc=182&flt=h&sub=all | title=Harvard bio | accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> She is an [[emeritus professor]] of [[psychology]] at the [[University of Bath]]. Haste also holds honorary visiting positions at the [[University of Exeter]], the [[Hong Kong Institute of Education]], and the [[University of Jinan]] China.

== Research ==
Haste's research focuses on young people's moral and political beliefs, and also on gender issues particularly in relation to science and culture. Her work on moral and political development and the civic engagement of young people has explored the factors that promote or inhibit participation in both conventional and unconventional forms of action. Haste is interested especially in how cultural narratives and metaphors are reflected in the development of young people's beliefs. Her work on science, society, and gender has explored the cultural images of science, how they reflect dominant models of rationality, how these are associated with conceptions of gender, and how they influence motivation to take up science interests. Alone or in collaboration with others she has worked on data from the UK, China, and South Africa. Haste is the author or editor of five books and over a hundred academic research paper and chapters. Books include ''The Sexual Metaphor'' ([[Harvard University Press]], 2004), ''Making Sense: the Child's Construction of the World'' (with Jerome Bruner: [[Routledge]] 1987), ''The Development of Political Understanding'' (with Judith Torney-Purta, [[Jossey-Bass]], 1992). She has also written numerous popular articles and has been a frequent broadcaster on British radio and television.

== Academic honours and service==
Haste is a Fellow of the [[British Psychological Society]],<ref name="Fellow of British Psychological Society">{{cite web |url=http://www.bps.org.uk/bpssearchablelists/fellows?frmAction=showUser&Mem_MemberKeys_Selected=8309 |title=Fellow of British Psychological Socieity |accessdate=20 May 2014 |subscription=yes}}</ref> a Fellow of the [[Academy of Social Science]] and a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]]. She is also an Honorary Fellow of the [[British Science Association]].<ref name="BSA fellowship">{{cite web |url=http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/about-british-science-association/our-organisation/honorary-fellows/current-honorary-fellows |title=BSA fellowship |date=2013 |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> She was president of the [[International Society of Political Psychology]] in 2002. Haste received the [[Nevitt Sanford]] award (2005)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ispp.org/awards/sanford |title=Nevitt Sanford Award |publisher=International Society of Political Psychology}}</ref> and the Jeanne Knutson award (2009) from that organization for her contributions to the field of [[political psychology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ispp.org/awards/Knutson |title=Awards & Recognitions |publisher=International Society of Political Psychology}}</ref> She received the Kuhmerker Award from the [[Association for Moral Education]] in 2011 for her lifelong contributions to [[moral education]]. For many years she was associated with the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] (now the British Science Association), serving as vice-president (2002-2008), chair of council (2002 -2004), and president of the Psychology Section in 1991.

From 2007-2013 Haste served as the chair of the [[editorial board]] of the ''[[Journal of Moral Education]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?show=editorialBoard&journalCode=cjme20 |title=Editorial board |work=Journal of Moral Education |publisher=[[Routledge]]}}</ref> From 2010-2015 she was co-editor of the journal ''[[Political Psychology (journal)|Political Psychology]]''.<ref name="Political psychology co-editor">{{cite web |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1467-9221/homepage/EditorialBoard.html |work=Political Psychology |title=Editorial board |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref>
